oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Treatment for Bovine Respiratory Disease in U.S. Feedlots
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Loneragan, Guy H.
Dargatz, David A.
Wagner, Bruce A.
Wineland, Nora E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bovine respiratory disease
stressors
animal susceptibility
pathogens
treatment
antimicrobial
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bovine respiratory disease complex (BRD) is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in U.S. feedlots. It is generally accepted that BRD results from an interaction of stressors, animal susceptibility and pathogens. Viral respiratory pathogens are believed to be primary invaders that allow bacterial colonization of the lower respiratory tract (LRT) which leads to bronchopneumonia. Prompt treatment of BRD-affected calves early in the course of disease with an appropriate antimicrobial appears to be the best strategy to effect a cure. Delayed or inappropriate treatment often leads to treatment failure, chronic disease, or death.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2002; 174
